#summary Tutorial and guide for developers

= Getting started =

  * Install the SWT/XML plugins in your Eclipse IDE (version 3.4) using the [http://code.google.com/p/swtxml/wiki/UpdateSite?tm=2 update site]

  * For playing around with SWT/XML create a Plug-in project and add a dependency to the "com.swtxml" plug-in

  * Create a new SWT/XML Class using File / New / Other - Other / SWT/XML Class. You need to specify a class name and the base type. Every SWT/XML markup file is accompanied by a  view class with the same name (which extends a SWT/XML base class):
    http://swtxml.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/img/class_swtxml.png

  * The markup file is opened automatically. You can get a preview for swtxml files with Window / Show View / Other / SWT/XML / SWT/XML Preview. It is updated whenever you save an active swtxml editor. The editor has full content assist for SWT/XML markup syntax, so you should be able to use Ctrl+Space everywhere.

= General Markup syntax =

  * The meaning of the XML is defined by its XML namespace. In the example above, the default xmlns is "http://www.swtxml.com/swt". This namespace maps SWT classes to XML - if you're familiar with SWT, you just need learn the conversion rules:
    {{{
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Composite xmlns="http://www.swtxml.com/swt">
</Composite>
    }}}


  * Every widget class becomes a XML tag. So you have <Button/>, <Text/>, <Label/> and so on:
    {{{
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Composite xmlns="http://www.swtxml.com/swt">
    <Button/>
</Composite>
    }}}
 

  * Composites can have childs - these are added to the parent: 
    {{{
<Composite>
    <Label/> 
    <Text/> 
</Composite> 
    }}}
 
  * Every setter method of the widget class is an attribute for the tag:
    {{{
<Button text="hello" enabled="false"/>
    }}}

  * Style constants can be specified using a comma separated list in the style attribute:
    {{{
<Button text="hello" style="TOGGLE,FLAT"/>
    }}}

= Layout markup =

  * Composite elements have a layout attribute which is interpreted in CSS-like syntax. Every setter / field of the Layout class is a property you can specifiy here: 
    {{{
<Composite layout="layout:grid; numColumns:3; marginTop:10; "/>
}}}

  * Inside a Composite, child tags can have a layoutData attribute. You can use all properties of the LayoutData class here:
    {{{
<Composite layout="layout:grid; numColumns:2; "> 
    <Label text="123" layoutData="widthHint:100;"/> 
    <Text text="456"/> 
</Composite> 
}}}

= Using the view class =

  * The view class (same location and name as the markup file) handles parsing the markup and creating the widgets.

  * You can implement the setup method to implement logic to be executed after the view was created.

  * You can use the widgets here by assigning an id="..." attribute in the markup and declaring an *@ById* annotated field. The field will be set by the SWT/XML parser.
    {{{
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Composite xmlns="http://www.swtxml.com/swt">
    <Button text="helloWorld" id="btnHelloWorld"/>
</Composite>
}}}
    {{{
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.*;
import com.swtxml.container.SwtXmlShell;
import com.swtxml.swt.byid.ById;

public class SwtWidgetsExamplesWindow extends SwtXmlShell {

	@ById
	private Button btnHelloWorld;

	@Override
	protected void setupView() {
		//do something with the widgets here
	}

}
}}}

= Events =

   * The namespace {{{http://www.swtxml.com/events}}} provides an attribute for every event listener method (like {{{widgetSelected}}} from {{{SelectionListener}}}). When the event is triggered, a method by that name is called on your view class (optional with event parameter):
    {{{
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Composite xmlns="http://www.swtxml.com/swt" xmlns:on="http://www.swtxml.com/events">
    <Button text="helloWorld" on:widgetSelected="onHelloClicked"/>
</Composite>
}}}
    {{{
public class SwtWidgetsExamplesWindow extends SwtXmlShell {

	private void onHelloClicked() {
		//handle event here
	}

}
}}}
